title: Customizable Universal Dove Slots Holder Etc

description.text:
Problem : Above a few Tens of parameters models get confusing
This is an experiment to explore contexted views in Customizer
Each tab presents a different view highlighting its parameters with a modify/done switch.
This facilities a pedagogic wizard-like walk trough of parameters

Please be a good sport and share pictures of successful prints. I means a lot to me.

https://openscadsnippetpad.blogspot.com/

comments.text:
Nicely done. Really easy to understand. I guess this is still work in progress? Anyway here a few ideas/bugfixes (I use version 2016.12.10):
a) Maybe you can change the switches to 0 and 1 with the explanation in brackets. (Easier handling.)
b) The H value (height) isn't working for me. Sticks to 100mm no matter the value.
This fixed it for me:
linear_extrude(H, convexity = 10, ..... instead of
linear_extrude(convexity = 10, H, .....
c) The hole pattern is static (you probably know this as it's not finished yet).
Idea(not polished):
HoleSize1 = 3; //also slotwidth
HoleSize2 = 4;
Plate1 = [ [ [0, H-20, HoleSize1], [0, 20, HoleSize1] ], [15, 20, HoleSize2], [-15, 20, HoleSize2], [15, H-20, HoleSize2], [-15, H-20, HoleSize2], [10, H/2, HoleSize1], [-10, H/2, HoleSize1]];
Plate2 = [ [ [0, H-20, HoleSize1], [0, 20, HoleSize1] ], [10, H/2, HoleSize1], [-10, H/2, HoleSize1]];
d) Maybe a few different hole patterns depending on the slot size (small ones need less holes, bigger ones more).
e) Maybe an option for no holes.
f) The parts that should get the holes aren't explained yet:
//parts 0=both \make = 0; //[1,2,0]; better:
//parts 0=both, 1= bottom, 2= top \make = 0; //[1,2,0] (I like the use of numbers here.)

b) H is a bug, thank you
c) I cant replicate that
Holes work like this
A list of
[ [ X,Y,R ] , [ X,Y,R ] , [ X,Y,R ] , [ X,Y,R ] ]

comments.text:

c) https://abload.de/img/holes_not_automaticlyn0jzk.png

comments.text:

The list of holes system is very versatile.
You can go pretty wild with Iterations for(), Assignments let() and Conditionals (ternary style) " Tested_Condition ? option_true : option_false " and most other math functions. todo build a way to define functions.
For example:
[let (QP = 0)[[QP, abs( H - A ) >= 100 ? 80 : 40, 3], [QP, 20, 3]]]
or Iterations like
[ for (i=[-A0.5:10:A0.5],j=[5:20:H-5])[ [i,j,2.5],[i,j+10,2.5]] ]
For larger patterns i edit the bulk in some notepad.

author: Torleif

title: Bronze Robot Warrior Apple Watch charger dock stand

description.text:
I made this for a 2 day workshop in evaporative casting in bronze using a styrene foam model. While the others carved their foam models by hand (achieving some beautiful and rustic results), I wanted to make a part which worked with my Apple Watch and charging button, so I had to be a little more precise in my model development. Enter the Roland MDX-40A Benchtop CNC Mill.

I was pleasantly surprised by the way the MDX-40A (and rotary attachment) reproduced my 3D model, and by the way the casting method made a part sufficiently faithful to the model so that it required just a basic clean up to fit the charger button.

The bronze piece relies on the weight of the bronze to stop the cable making it pitch forward rather than sit flat on a surface. To counter this in a 3D printed part, you could use double-sided tape to try to stick the cable into the channel, or stick the piece down to another surface.

I've designed a companion base cap piece to contain the spring force from the cable. There is a 0.3mm tolerance from the surface of the main part for a snug fit.

I measured up all the parts and modelled the piece using Rhinoceros.

I milled the part a few times out of blue extruded insulation styrene board, trying different end mills, stepover and toolpath options. The bronze pour was pretty exciting to watch. Look closely and you'll see the fumes from the evaporating foam coming through the sand.

author: CBarros

title: Anet A8 Frame Braces w/Y-Axis Belt Tension Rods

description.text:
Matsekberg came up with a cool idea to take Y-axis belt tension off the front frame panel by introducing threaded rods on each side of the belt, similar to X-belt tension transferred to the carriage rods. This thereby reduces the need for frame bracing.

I didn't see this as a REPLACEMENT for frame braces, rather than an ADDITION to them, so I took the idea to it's ultimate conclusion: I refined the parts, then I merged them all together with existing frame braces.

I have printed and installed this system on my printer, everything is aligned & fits snug. There are apparently issues with parts from Anet which were made with holes off-center, but this system functions fine with a properly produced frame. The belt tensioner now works with 8.5mm x 13mm 16 & 20 tooth aluminum idler pulleys, use an M3*18 screw for all idler pulleys. If slicer fails to correctly print recesses in idler tension arm, use a candle to heat nut to melt it in, same with bolt head. If they aren't recessed, the tension rods will interfere... I have reworked this design many times since initially posting it, download latest version before printing.

I used a three foot long 1/4" zinc plated threaded rod from my local hardware store. One meter long of 6mm diameter is the metric equivalent. Add with it 4 corresponding nuts & two washers for this build. Cut short side to 30.5cm, cut longer side to 34.5cm. You're looking at $4 total material cost.

The original concept is found here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2045010
The original frame braces found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1430727

comments.text: I'm going to try to remix this to add the stepper motor brace as seen in ykimhi's remix (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2350830) of matsekberg's original.

comments.author: LittleMrJ

comments.text:
The entire purpose of a front frame brace is to reinforce the acrylic frame panel, as belt tension will, over time, slowly bend the acrylic. My little system here removes belt tension from the front frame entirely. The front acrylic frame piece isn't actually needed now, other than for a shiny accessory. The back brace stiffens everything else up a bit, and makes the system functional. It was an experiment, a mashup of 3 other designs. I'm satisfied with it, as my frame is very ridged, & mounted to a base. Sorry some people have issue with it, I realize how long this takes & how much filament it uses.
I wasn't suggesting buying different bearing blocks. I designed my own: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2274088
As far as the M3 holes, I should just remove them too, so everyone can drill their own holes to line up to their specific frames.

title: Centrifugal fan duct for Vector3 3D Printer

description.text:
I designed this fan shroud for the Vector3 3D Printer from Eaglemoss to replace the wimpy fans supplied with the magazine.

Everything should print with zero supports or supports touching buildplate only.

The fan was from Amazon, it's the 24V 50mm centrifugal fan and 40mm axial fan twin pack by HICTop, other fans may work but I offer no guarantee as the fan duct press fits inside the fan exhaust.

The plate and duct press fit together and the duct press fits into the fan exhaust. Secure them together with a nut/bolt through the top fan screw hole and then secure the entire assembly onto the print head with a self tapping screw through the bottom fan screw hole into the bottom right post of the print head.

Vector3

description.text:
Have made this cooler for the Duplicator 6. This cooler works with a so-called turbo cooler and ensures that the model is properly cooled. Is currently still in testing, soon pictures of the model printed on the Wanhao Duplicator 6 3D printer!

v3 version (15-04-2017)

  • Uploaded a beta version of the new v3 duct (STEP file). Note that this is not finished yet, and maybe not even fit (good)!

New v3 version?

  • Need YOUR feedback (post it by the comments) to make the new v3 fanduct!

v2.1 version

  • Added a 'peek' hole, so you can see the nozzle
  • Make the blow holes bigger, for more airflow
  • Added some room on the top, for the cooler cable
  • Some improvements for easyer print (less big overhangs)
  • Added some 'core' files!

v2 version

  • Easy printing!
  • Goes all the way around the nozzle
  • Maximum 45 degrees overhangs
  • Easily printed nozzles (from building board)
  • Thick walls (4x2 lines of 0.40)

For now it's only fit's a 50mm turbofan from ebm papst (http://nl.farnell.com/ebm-papst/rlf35-8-14n/blower-radial-51mm-24vdc/dp/1293483?aa=true&vw&categoryId=700000005518&eq=N%3D203782%2B2021%26amp%3BNs%3DP_STORE_MARKETING_RANK_FARNELL_NL%257c0%257c%257cP_MAN_PART_NUM%257c0%26amp%3BNtpc%3D1%26amp%3BNtpr%3D1&searchView=table&iscrfnonsku=false). Will work on other versions!

'uncleskippy' hass make a remix for a 40x40x20mm fan! You can find the STL here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2204314

FlashForge

Printer:

FlashForge Creator Pro

Only use support for onder the big bridge (see Simplify3D screenshot). This design is fully optimized for a 0.40 nozzle.

description.text:
This is a demonstration piece useful for studying and understanding the geometry behind the rising dovetail joint. IT can also serve as a fidget for someone who likes woodworking jpints. The 2 parts slide together to create what looks like an impossible wood joint. A 0.01" (0.25mm) tolerance gap was included on the .STL to allow an easy fit straight off the printer without much, if any, post print filing.

Also included is the OpenSCAD version, which allows for the male part with the tongue to be generated, the female part with the tongue cut out to be generated, and the ability to adjust the tolerance gap on both so the fit is easier straight off the printer. Use the Customizer to make this Rising Dovetail exactly the shape you want! Check it out.

NOTE: preview for female part looks a little weird, but exports to STL just fine. Trying to figure out a solution. Any suggestions?

Updated (3/4/17) Customizer OpenSCAD file updated to include an option to create the male or female part and preview both together (don'T export the both option!!!)! Still working on making the tolerance gap function work. (Option in Customizer doesn't do anything yet.) (also trying to resolve the wierdness in preview of female joint and both in customizer. The part looks fine when the STL file is created. I'm assuming I need to extrude the negative of the tongue part slightly past the block. Any suggestions? To be continued...)

Updated (3/9/17) Tolerance gap added! Half of tolerance shaved off male part and half shaved off female part.NExt thinking about trying to make the tongue and the tongue cutout into modules so they can be placed into other locations or multiple locations...

Updated 3/17/17 converted much of the code to use modules, simplifying the code and allowing for possibility of adding future customizer options. Thinking about adding capability of including multiple joints on a single part...

description.text:
A music box for my daughter that plays "our" song. It's designed to mount a music box mechanism by Sankyo. Search online and you can find just about any classic tune for your music box for around $15.

Test spin: https://youtu.be/PCwhPuNIGCk
Note, for the video the statue was only taped on top and the box was on an unlevel surface, so the music runs slow and fast.

You'll need the optional extension shaft from your Sankyo music box to power the rotating fairy. Available here for $0.95:
http://www.whittemoredurgin.com/7177-smoothshaft

You'll need 2x 10mm M3 bolts to secure the music box mechanism to the base and 6x 10-15mm M3 bolts to secure the base to the outer case.

The statue was remixed from pixalism's "Degas Girl" at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1200209. I smoothed over the nipples and vulva and tweaked the hair, then added some wings.

If you want to customize the box design, use the "Outer case blank" box file. My technique is to create a design in Inkscape, export it as a .SVG, import it into Tinkercad, make it into a hole, and subtract from the case.

Finally, the upper 2 bolt holes on the inner case are somewhat misaligned. Just use the lower 2 for now.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Be sure to print the outer box upside down!

I painted the body and base with metallic silver acrylic paint, then washed in black and wiped off highlights. I painted the wings in metalic bronze acrylic paint and curved them gently by placing on a curved surface and heating with a heat gun.

comments.text: Print with 3 solid surface layers, 2 extra shells on alternatingsurface layers, and be sure your flow rate and line spacing is set properly.   I use 1.5 for line spacing (infill width over thickness) If there is even the tiniest of gaps between the lines on the solid surface layers, it won't work.  Also I use a .3 for infill perimeter overlap.

print_settings.Notes:: This took about 30 hours on my printer with 15% infill, it could easily be done and strong enough with 10% though.

description.text:
I made this since we use a spray cleaner on our board pretty regularly and i wanted all items for the board to be in one spot. So this holds up to 6 markers, because i like colors, the eraser for the board, and a spray bottle up to 5.5 cm in diameter. We got ours at the dollar store, but it also fits the ones made by Expo.

Two designs are attached:

  • The first design has screw holes to be used on both the top and the bottom side of the design. This design must be printed using the flat side which would be placed on the wall being down on the printer bed. Printing without supports is doable but makes the eraser holder a bit messy, printing with supports will require some cleanup inside the design. This design does provide more stability, but I have found that this is not really necessary.

  • The second design has screw holes only in the top side of the design. This is better for printing as it allows the design to be printed from the bottom up rather than using the wall side of the object. I have found that the strength from just the two screws is more than sufficient.

I did have to turn the object sideways to fit the print bed for my printer which is 200mm X 200mm, so if your slicer is showing it as not printable try rotating it and moving it around at a 45 degree angle and that should work.

As a side note I did also install two very large dry erase boards (3'X4' and 4'X5') in my office at home for less than $50. We went to Home depot and got a 4x8 ft white panel which has a plastic coat over the top. This was actually marked as dry erase board in the store, but their website does not seem to have it. We then got carpet strips in order to frame it and some 1.5" wide head nails of the same color as the carpet strip. we used something similar to this, http://www.homedepot.com/p/TrafficMASTER-Silver-Hammered-144-in-x-1-3-8-in-Carpet-Trim-06940/100179516.

  1. Cut the erase board down to the size of the white board you want in your office using a razor of some kind and a straight edge such as a ruler or meter stick.

  2. Use tin snips or a hack saw to cut the carpet strips to the length that you want. Keep in mind that you want the interior square of your carpet strips to be slightly less than the edge of the white board itself. so if you cut the whiteboard to be 3' X 3', then the carpet strips should be something like 2'11" X 2'11".The cuts should be at 45 degrees so that it forms a frame around the white board. Think about the cuts before you make them so that you don't waste too much material and to ensure that the inside edge of the strip is the shorter side.

  3. Attach the bottom carpet strip to the wall making sure to level the strip. Do not nail it down flat, keep enough gap to slip in the erase board.

  4. Put the dry erase board on the wall, resting the bottom edge on the nails used to put up the bottom carpet strip. You can now nail these nails the rest of the way in to make it tight.

  5. nail on the other pieces of carpet strip around the edge of the white board to hold it in place firmly and complete the appearance of a frame.

Printer:

ANET A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.1mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

This took about 30 hours on my printer with 15% infill, it could easily be done and strong enough with 10% though.

Design process

I designed this using Sketchup at a large scale and then scaled it down. I intentionally left a low polygon count on the circles as I like the appearance of multiple straight edges. I also left the eraser holder with a flat blank face so that text can be easily added to customize your print.

title: 10 Die Slim 9.5 x 3 mm dice holder - remix

description.text:
I printed these during a time when my heated bed was broken so I had a lot of first layer issues. The wooden one was terrible, first layer curled up and it warped. I was going to throw it away but it looks really antique so I like it.
The guys in my group want me to make an antique warped one for them too now.

This is a remix of an outstanding creation by Triton_9.
It is essentially his design, all I did was change the magnet holes a little. They are now 9.5mm x 3mm deep to accommodate the magnets I have at my local Home Depot. The magnets are Super Magnets .3in x .11in (8mmx3mm). The holes are wide enough to fit these magnets and allow a little glue to seep up the sides so they can be held in firmly.

Support needed for screw and nut holes. But that should be very little all together.

Screws go through the post and the narrower part of the posts go inside the openings of the board to lock everything in place. Hex nuts are used on the bottom to fasten the screws in place.

remixed_from.author: jamesarm97
remixed_from.title: Wanhao Duplicator I3 Controller replacement backplate

title: MakerSelect Wanhao Rear Plate with relay control

description.text:
This is a replacement contol box rear plate for a Maker Select. I have a Maker Select V2 and I have printed and test fit these on it. I am running Octoprint on a Raspberry Pi that is installed in the main housing of a custom created version of a PiClop scanner, but I wanted to be able to control some add ons I made for my printer without a bunch of ugly wires. This was designed to be able to mount a Siemon Cat6 keystone jack on the back of the control box, allowing you to use any ethernet patch cord to control a Sainsmart 4ch relay board (or similar device) with a nice clean look.

There are a few files included to allow you to modify as needed or create your own designs:

  1. boardMounts2.stl: The mounting plate I made for inside the control box. THIS WILL REQUIRE DRILLING HOLES IN THE METAL HOUSING FOR 2 M3 SCREWS. The heads will be visible on top of the box. There are already two M5 screws there, and I used socket cap screws that matched and I think they look fine. This stl allows you to mount a Sainsmart 4ch realy and the MOSFET mod board cleanly inside.

  2. MK2RearPanel.stl: This is the panel I chose to use and the ones featured in the pics. It allows for the original power plug/switch/fuse panel, original 40mm fan, and adds a hole for the jack.

  3. MK2RearPanelDual.stl: Basically the same as before, but slightly rearranged to allow for a second 40mm fan.

  4. MK2RearPanelBlank.stl: The Maker Select control box rear cover with NO cutouts to easily make your own design.

  5. seimon_mount.stl: This is a mounting plate for another keystone jack on the other device. It includes a backplate for inside the other device enclosure and a front trim/mount that goes on the outside. My scanner body took 20 hours to print and I had not planned to add this at that time. I did not want to reprint it so this was my solution. It allows a not-so-pretty hole to be cut in your existing print or store bought enclosure and it will hide the nasty and look nice. You can use the backplate piece as a template for your hole.

  6. seimon_jack.stl: The cut out for mounting a Seimon Cat6 keystone jack. I used the angle style because it was all I had on hand, but a straight one will look far nicer. You can use this file to boolean out holes in the included MK2RearPanelBlank.stl or in a design of your own. This was created from measurements of an actual Seimon faceplate. The important thing to remember is the larger face must remain at the 2mm thickness it currently is or the jack will not snap in. the smaller area is the actual jack opening. That can be made thicker as needed for your material, but keep in mind an angle jack will hit if you go any thicker than included.

  7. 40mm_fan_knockout.stl: Just as it says. You can use this to make a boolean to create a nice area to mount a 40mm fan including screw holes.

WIRING:
Ethernet wiring:
I punched a bit of cat 6 without the jacket (just the pairs) on the jacks. You can wire the jacks however you want as long as it matches on both ends. MAKE SURE YOU NEVER PLUG THIS INTO YOUR ROUTER, PC, OR OTHER ETHERNET DEVICE!! I used the following layout:
Orange/White: N/A - Will likely use for a pushbutton in the future.
Orange: 5vdc to Sainsmart from Pi
Blue/White: Sainsmart relay 1 trigger.
Blue: Sainsmart relay 2 trigger.
Green/White: Sainsmart relay 3 trigger.
Green: Sainsmart relay 4 trigger.
Brown/White: N/A - Will likely use for a pushbutton in the future.
Brown: Ground to Sainsmart from Pi

Relay Wiring:
R1 - Printer power. I used this relay to interrupt the AC line voltage into the power supply. Since the 5v feeding the relay comes from the pi in another enclosure with a different supply, you can turn power on/off to the printer remotely. BE EXTREMELY CAREFUL WITH AC POWER! THIS CAN KILL YOU OR DAMAGE YOUR EQUIPMENT.

R2 - Enclosure Lighting. I have 120vac LED rope lighting in my enclosure. I used the same AC feed I used for R1, then cut the female side of an extension cord and ran it out the back. I can control the enclosure lighting remotely as I like to leave it off unless needed to view the camera.

R3 - Extruder light. I created an LED strip mount for my extruder for extra light. Extremely useful in person, washes out my camera when viewing remotely so its nice to have the control.

R4 - Currently unused, but you can let your imagination go wild!

EDIT: I have found out that the switch on the side of the LCD on the Maker Select is a backlight toggle. When I get some time to play around I will post an update of how to do this. Depending whether a pwm signal dims it or not will change what I do. If dimming works I will likely use the two extra wires in the cat6 to make that happen. If it is not an option then I will likely use relay 4 to be able to toggle the backlight.

Software
I used the Octoprint plugin found here: https://github.com/vitormhenrique/OctoPrint-Enclosure

This was remixed from the Wanhao Duplicator I3 Controller replacement backplate by jamesarm97 that can be found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:853541

comments.text: This is a really nice looking upgrade and I'm gathering all the materials needed to do it and the MOSFET upgrade.  Do you mind telling me what size screws you used to screw the relay board and MOSFET to the mounting plate you made?
comments.author: nobled

comments.text: I'm happy with everything so far and don't think I would have done much differently. Eventually I may make an entire new power supply enclosure with a higher output power supply and a better layout to allow for more space for wiring and airflow, as well as a larger and quieter fan.
comments.author: nobled

comments.text: I used M3x6 socket cap screws. The zmod requires swapping the original 5-6mm ones with 10-15mm ones, and I used the original screws that were removed from the printer.
comments.author: nobled

comments.text: Thanks for the info!  Unfortunately, the Home Depot in my area doesn't stock many of the metric screws so I had to order them from Amazon (they literally had 2 of the M3 x 10mm screws in stock).  I actually want to do the relay mod so I don't have to go turn on my printer before I send something to octoprint running on a raspberry pi and thought if I'm installing relays I might as well do the MOSFET while I'm at it and might wire in an outlet to the back as well so I can install some LEDs.  I'm also doing a z-axis and leveling feet mod too in the hopes of having to take my machine apart as few times as possible, but we'll see how it works out...

Here we have a vibrating trough feeder!
I designed this little guy as a top up hopper for a small bowl feeder. It will perform well even when loaded up fully with metallic parts.

In addition to the printed parts, you will need a vibrating motor (from eBay), 6 x m3x6 socket head cap screws, a little PWM controller and a DC power supply.

A video of this running can be found here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5BFWx2Iu-GE&t=85s

description.text:
This is a simple remix of the Monoprice Select Mini E3Dv6 Zero Offset Mount by USWaterRockets. No major changes just tweaks to tighten the fit and beef up the fan mount holes. Also constricted the layer fan jet and placed a thin wall for the led holes for those who don't want the leds just yet. I enlarged the 'ears' to allow more room for wires and zip ties.

I have video of the assembly and wiring:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=R8sZbwOS8hQ

Also note you will likely have to file the layer fan nozzle opening to the size desired. I kept it tight but you can open it up as much as you find works for you.

I printed the 0 offset carrier at .0875 with 30% fill
The bracket and Led fan at .0875 with 100% fill
I used Hatchbox PETG and it came out quite nicely.

comments.text: I love that you shared a video how to make the swap of parts. thank you for that. I too would like to make this but with 40 mm fans. could you either share the CAD files or maybe publish a new thing with 40 mm fans?

description.text:
I needed a bunch of rear lens caps for Fuji X-Mount lenses when I picked up some lens adapters for my old M42 and Olympus manual primes. Rather than buy a 3rd party set off eBay (or pay Fuji's ridiculous prices!), I thought I'd spin up a replacement in OpenSCAD and try printing them.

They are based on similar dimensions to the official caps, and I designed it with grip notches to give it similar ergonomics to the injection molded original.

I've included the OpenSCAD script in case you wish to make any changes - the STL and default values in the script are for most normal lenses and adapters, but if you have a lens that has elements that extend past the mount then you may wish to increase the internal_depth value to 12mm, for instance.

Finally, the text on the front is configurable, in case you want a personalized design :)

Printer:

Prusa i3 Mk2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.10mm layer height, 0.40mm nozzle

Infill:

20%

Notes:

This printed well on my Original Prusa i3 MK2 in Rigid.Ink PLA (1.75mm), using Slic3r (Prusa edition). Because of the angled inner lugs and the acute front face edges, you probably want to do this at as fine layer height as possible (I used 0.1mm).

The supports that I found to work best were rectilinear grid.

NOTE: Make sure to rotate the model 180deg (flat face down) for printing.

description.text:
Here we go! The long awaited MKII 3d printed vibrating bowl feeder.

In addition to the printed parts, you are going to need some 8mm hard chrome bar, a flanged 8mm linear bearing (LMF8UU) and a handful of small M3 fasteners. The actual motor is a 385(Update - this may be incorrect) frame sized "Vibrating motor" from ebay. Yup - it's the one for adult entertainment. You will also want a PWM controller (I've found the slightly higher quality ones hold their rev's more consistently) a power supply and some hook up wire. There is a cut out in the base for mounting a 35mm(maybe - best to measure the pocket) cooling fan, but this really isn't necessary.

Assembly is fairly straightforward. The parts mostly clip together, or else are held in place with M3x10 cap screws. The 8mm hard chrome bar will need to be cut to length. I found this easiest to do before assembling the 'Vibro Base Chassis', 'Vibro Base Top Pad' and the 'Dog Bone's, plus the LMF8UU bearing, and then passing the rod through and cutting to length. You only need about 3mm of travel, so the motor mount can be fairly near the top of the chassis.

If you do make one of these, please put an "I made one" photo up - it's always great to see my designs out in the wild!

A video of this running can be found here; https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hkNtlXqbp94&t=7s

You can find our other projects using the links below;

http://www.vikingmachinery.co.nz/

https://grabcad.com/james.hussey-3

Instagram; james_viking_machinery

remixed_from.author: 3dprintspace
remixed_from.title: PiGRRL Zero - Modified for Speakers and Standoff Screws!

description.text:
This is a remix of Jpete24 PiGrrl with audio and standoffs.

I order the Audio Jack from Amazon:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00HG7H6TI/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o07_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

I ordered the HDMI adapter from Amazon:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00BQVK2PU/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o04_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

I started by stripping the rubber sheath off of the micro HDMI to HDMI adapter.
I then cut a square hole in the front of the case big enough for the Micro HDMI to HDMI adapter to fit. Once it fit correctly, I glued it into place.

For the audio adapter, I drilled an 1/8 inch hole in the side, threaded the top through, and glued it into place. I followed the wiring diagram from here: http://chemelec.com/Projects/Metal-2a/Metal-2.htm.

The only drawback with this setup is that the speaker is not switched off when the headphones are inserted, they just get quieter. On the plus side, turning the volume down low enough so that it no longer comes from the speakers makes it the perfect volume for the headphones. It is probably possible to get the speaker to cut out completely with additional resistor but I have not looked into this solution yet.

The speaker could removed and the headphone jack would work for audio too if you just want headphones.

I create a faceplate to glue onto the front of the modified D-Pad (which was provided by Galvatrondeva at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2011391) to hide the internals and make it look more finished without having to modify the case I already printed. I was having difficulty with multiple button presses or wrong button presses on the d-pad with the original d-pad design. Galvatrondeva's d-pad works great.

I am currently working on a script that launches at start up that will automatically detect if an HDMI device is connected. If so, it will launch one config file so that video and sound can be played through the HDMI device. Otherwise, it will load the modified pigrrl zero config. Check back for updates later.

At some point I will probably remix the case to include the button faceplate and the cutout for the hdmi port so check back later.

comments.text: Would I be able to hook this up to TV, and have a USB controller plugged into the usb to play two player on TV?
comments.author: KlassicKent

comments.text: That's what my goal is.  I want to be able to play multiplayer on the TV and also have it be portable for road trips.  Currently, it doesn't quite work, the HDMI detects a monitor is attached but doesn't display on it.  I'm working on a python script to change the config file on startup depending on if the HDMI detects anything.  Unfortunately I haven't had much time to work on this since I have been moving but should get to work on it more soon.  I'll upload the files when I get it working.

description.text:
M filter Cartridge - Use "Blue Bonded Filter Pads" cheap from your local pet store - the ones that have 2 distinct materials white side and blue side so it can be easily pulled apart, lay the white side on the "back part.. Tabs up" then add some activated carbon... carefully line up holes with the top part and lightly tap together with hammer and cut excess filter fabric...

Keep in mind the tabs are very fragile, this is version 2, improvements include; reduction in material and print time (thickness was reduced), added cross brace to top side and improved tab and hole design.

Hello again, This is a LCD relocation for the zonestar P802NR2. My printer is up to high to make the controls easy to use. There were several on Thingiverse but the button holes were to far from the edge of the LCD screen. Check your spacing before printing and wasting filament like I did. My LCD is 5 mm from the first button. I hope this fills a need. It was designed in 123Design. I did not put screw holes to secure the screen as you can use double stick tape or small screws. I used screws and used a small drill bit to make a hole. With the infill being so light don't tighten the screws to tight. B-p The Box back is a tight fit so it shouldn't need anything to hold it. But it is hard to open.

comments.text: Hi. Nice design. Will this work with the TronXY P802M? Thanks in advance!
comments.author: michel9311

comments.text:
I didn't print this one yet but I have both the LCD of the tronxy 802M and the one for Zonestar (bought an upgrade kit and made the necessary adjustements...). There are two differences between the Zonestar and the Tronxy LCD screens:
1) There are two connectors on the back (Zonestar) instead of one (Tronxy)
2) Zonestar's LCD has a SD Card reader on the side, while the Tronxy has it on the Melzi motherboard itself (and that's what the second connector on the back is for.
Size of display and distance of buttons are exactly the same. You can just print this file as is, you'll just end up with a slightly larger hole on the back than you actually need and a side hole that you don't really need. Or you can tinker the stl up on tinkercad or other editing sofware and reduce the back hole and "plug" the side one.
comments.author: michel9311

comments.text:
Hi Michel
I looked at the printer it looks like a clone of a clone so I am not sure. Print the first 3-4 layers with screen and buttons face down and then stop the printing and see if opening and button placement work. At least that is what I would do. Print .3 and 15infill to test. If it fits please let me know and I will add it to my list.
I hope this helps.
Bryant

title: Camera Mount For Durafly Tundra R/C Airplane

description.text:
This is my first shot at designing a simple part for my Hobby King Tundra R/C Airplane. I wanted a good safe place to mount my Runcam2 or Mobius camera. I have seen people mount cameras on top of the wing on the window decal but that can easily come off and you lose your camera. Screw that! Took me a while but I think I got it.

I mount all my cameras using industrial strength extreme velcro brand velcro. I may design a mount that will accept a safety strap of some type.

I'm also going to design a version with a GoPro adapter for you GoPro guys!

I designed this part in FreeCAD, exported as a .stl file and used Simplify3D for slicing.

This is my second and final design. Should print on most printers under 50min. tops.

Big Shout-out to JohnVH Photography For The EPIC Tundra Photo's! TEAM C/L FTW!!!!

Photos demonstrate use on a small CNC machine to create a temporary zero location allowing repeatability between tool changes.

description.text:
I have an '85 Chevy Suburban with a bench seat. I wanted a cupholder for the truck, but didn't want to mount anything on the dash.
There's a great spot on the transmission hump next to the 4wd shifter, so I designed a simple cupholder in OpenSCAD and printed it out. Works great.

This could probably work in a variety of other applications as well. I included the original OpenSCAD code, so it should be fairly simple to adjust sizes for some other applications.

Print 1 top, 1 base, and 4 pillars.

UPDATE: I decided I wanted the cupholder to be level. The transmission hump on my truck is angled, so I made a new base that is wedge shaped. I added a recess into the bottom of the wedge and epoxied in a heavy weight (a chunk of steel bar). This works great. The original files are still here, but I have added the wedge as a separate file as well as the new combined base.

The cup holes are fairly large, so they will fit large sodas or some of my big coffee mugs I use while traveling. However they will hold regular size soda cans as well, since the top will keep them from moving too much.

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX v2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

25-35%

Notes:

Supports are needed for the screw holes that connect the top and bottom to the pillars. I use a pretty large air gap specification in my support settings, so the support structure pops out easily.

If you don't want to print with supports, you can edit the OpenSCAD file to not recess the screw heads and just have an open hole starting from the bottom surface.

description.text:
Here is another improved left extruder cooling duct for the FashForge creator pro with before and after performance examples. I measured and created the existing duct in SolidWorks. From this design, I created a duct that directs the air inward from three radial directions. This is a drop in replacement with no interference issues in a standard machine purchased in Jan 2016. There are files for both SLA and FDM manufacture - be sure to use the correct STL file when printing.

The picture shows an SLA test print, and an FDM test print with the old style duct and the new duct. Meltink Cool White PLA/PHA is used with an extruder temperature of 220C and the heated bed at 60C for the FDM models. The extruder temperature is close to the limit for that material (230C) to exacerbate the need for cooling. The results are clear.

comments.text: For PLA or PLA/PHA, try somewhere in the middle range of the recommended filament settings erring on the higher side, and set the bed temperature to 60C.  In the case of MeltInk PLA/PHA, which currently suggests 205C~230C, I would try 220C.  Since I only did one iteration and happened to drop the piece I printed at this temperature breaking one of the merlons, I would try 230C for better layer adhesion.  Never the less try somewhere in the middle range erring on the higher side.  For ABS, the bed temperature should be 100C and warping will be a challenge.

comments.text: Could you please explain how you achieved this effect?
comments.author: luksab

comments.text:
Well basically you choose the figures you want to try and also choose an angle where you want to see the effect, you take each figure moves in (+ x) and the other in (-x) at the same distance from the center, I moved 2cm from the center to one and -2cm from the center to the other.
Then extrude each piece into the desired angle, for example: 150 ° one and 30 ° the other.
You make a boolean of the intersection.
The trick is to use the Z-projection of that intersection to create the effect, in my case select the border and erase all the interior vertices, with that you already have the template to be able to extrude a part already with the effect.

Designed to re-enforce the foam in the front of my wing from it's removal for the lipo. I'm using 4S 1550 Tattu and 4S 1500 Bonka packs. The bay is not designed to the sit the full battery in, only to re-enforce the foam, and sit half way down. It probablt fits many other lipo brands. I use two of these in parallel for half hour flights.

This is a structural component - I'd print 100% infill at 0.15mm layers a little hotter than normal. (To melt it together well and avoid layer separation.) Then, I glue all sides of this bay on to the wing. I find this helps, greatly, avoid damage on crashes and landings. Because, let's face it - if you put lipos up front on a wing, that's a weak spot in said wing.

title: Voltage Alarm and Frsky X8R Housing for Emax Nighthawk Pro 280

description.text:
A basic housing to mount to the top plate of the Emax Nighthawk Pro 280 which provides a secure location for a Frsky X8r mount and a run-of-the-mill voltage alarm.

Features:
-Has elongated pegs to slot into the top plate openings
-Notches for cable ties which hold the enclosure down and secure the devices
-Channel for smart port cable and rx antennae

Bugs to work out:
-Plugging lipo into the voltage alarm inadvertently presses the button to change alarm voltage threshold
-Elongated pegs can require trimming in order to fit into the top plate slots
-Front corners can run into screws attaching top plate to standoffs

Changelog:
2/24/2017
-Enlarged screwdriver holes in the rear
-Added installation instructions

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select V2

Infill:

15%

Trimming

Trimming may be necessary for the pegs to fit into the top plate slots.

Installation
  1. Place on top plate; evaluate and rectify any need for trimming to fit into the slots until you are happy with the fit.
  2. Insert X8R, feeding antennae through the channel out the other end.
  3. If using smart port, feed cable up through the channel and use appropriate tools to plug it into the X8R.
  4. Insert Battery Voltage Alarm
  5. Secure entire assembly with cable ties using the provided notches.

title: XT60 heat plate mount for strain relief

description.text:
This thing will securely hold an XT60 connector on the side of my printer's heated bed, so that the wires going to the solder pads cannot be stressed by anyone or anything pulling on these wires, and so that the heated bed will be removable for maintenance or whatever.

To this end I used an XT60 connector, which is rated to support way more current than will flow through these wires to the heated bed. I designed this plastic mount to hold the XT60 connector firmly, using a screw hole that is in the heated bed in between the solder pads.

In the photos the screws are way too long. I'll fix that with my dremel tool and a cutoff wheel. Two 12mm and one 7mm M3 screws would be perfect. I didn't have those, so I used longer ones, which I'll trim to length.

As printed originally, the fit of the XT60 connector was a little too tight. Rather than tweak the dimensions in Solidworks in the source files, I simply tweaked the outer wall offset by a small amount to fix the symptom. It fit OK with -.12mm perimeter "horizontal expansion" in Cura.

I included the Solidworks sources in case anyone wants to fix or tweak this in whatever way.

Edit 8 MARCH 2017: just added STEP file versions of the sources for these two parts.

remixed_from.title: Z Axis linear bearing spacer for Thing-O-Matic

description.text: A spacer for LMB61014 to use without retaining ring.

While living in a land of metrics, finding the right linear bearings to fit my TOM was not easy but i finally found them.
The retaining ring on the other hand was another story. Obviously nothing is impossible but waiting for weeks was not an option. So i made this spacer which has a (sorta anyway) built in retaining ring. Just add som stripes to keep them in place and thatÂ´s it! They go in pairs, two per bearing.
I use them on my Z and Y-Stage. See pictures. The LMB 61014 are made by IKO and those fit the 9,525mm rods.

title: Bell Siphon with Snorkel and Cup for Aquaponics

description.text:
This is a bell siphon design, inspired by Bigelow Brook Farm's design on YouTube.

It is designed around a 40mm stand pipe mount outer diameter and is 250mm tall.

I have left the lid part off in the design so that I can glue in a clear piece to test it.

You can edit the OpenSCAD file, put in the dimensions that you need for your system and it should all scale accordingly.

I have not printed this full size yet.
The image is a PLA version at half scale to see if everything fits.

The bell siphon its self is designed to be printed upside down.

I was going to wait until I had tested the full version before uploading this, but I have had some interest, so I decided to put it up now as a work in progress.

Thanks to Preston Hackspace for the use of the Ultimaker Original 3D Printer to test this design out.

Designed in OpenSCAD

The OpenSCAD file that I used is attached.

The soldering assistant is a project idea I had to have my soldering supplies conveniently in one spot. The Solder spool holder is close to the work area to have a ready supply of solder to feed directly from the spool. The soldering assistant also features and adjustable vise to hold your projects securely as you assemble them. Just behind the work area is a parts bin, to put your resistors, capacitors, IC's tweezers or other supplies. Side "fins" make it possible to make custom add-ons that can just snap into place. The only part that isn't printable through a 3d printer is the center threaded rod that moves the base, this is a 1/4" threaded rod that can be purchased at any local hardware store. 2 hex nuts are also required, one that fits into the moving side of the platform, and one on the stationary side. An update will soon be done, addition to the design will be a fume extractor and adjustable angle for the vice platform. This is an entry for the "Make it real Challenge" contest on the instructables website. If you like the design, please vote for my design. http://www.instructables.com/id/Soldering-Assistant/
This Design was made to simply snap together, and requires little extra hardware from the 3D print. Assemble the pieces according to the model image, and you're good to go.

As I was organizing my living room, and I have only 2 remotes left, I thought 'What if I could have an organized way to store and charge my Siri Remote at once? So I came up with the Siri Remote Dock. I've been using it for a little while now, and for me it works perfectly!

It is designed to keep the lighting adapter in place by itself, and keep the damage to the cable to a minimum. My cable hasn't damaged from several try-outs with different models.

I printed it on a Craftbot Plus, without any support, and 40mm/s, but faster should be okay as well, depending on your printer I guess!

I hope you guys like it!

author: Yah01

title: 10mm LED Bicycle Chain Style Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I wanted to create a string of LEDs for a flexible display panel.
Original idea was to make a 16x16 colour change panel... however after experimenting with flexibility in mind this simple design evolved.

Wiring is simple with these slow colour change 10mm LEDs, parallel.

LEDs are way too bright to see with the naked eye, there is a trick at hand to place a screen of either Paper
or in my case thin polystyrene (depron), by altering the distance/angle to the led you can get a multitude of effects.

The fun begins when you alter the shape of the chain.
The great thing is the chain keeps the orientation and alignment of the LEDs so they point symmetrically forwards.

comments.author: povlhp

title: ostrich eggshell bowl with a hole for an ostrich feather

description.text:
This is a simple bowl to hold an ostrich eggshell and a feather of an ostrich (optional). There is just a little hole to hold a feather behind the eggshell, just look the pictures I added.
My wife was crying because of a damaged eggshell so I decided to print something to hold the second eggshell safe in place and maybe be goodlooking aswell. Simple but effective, looks great if you print it golden or black, tested both.

Now I have to print even more of them - for friends and family...

Notes:

printer: Anet A8 (customized)
slicer: Simplify3D
speed: 100mm/s
infill: 20%
supports: none
wall layers: 3
top and bottom layers: 3

filament: Gold Camel PLA 1.75mm
color: gold
temps: 190°C/50°C

comments.text: So where exactly does one acquire an ostrich eggshell?
comments.author: ThunderChild1

comments.text: I'm living in germany here we have so called ostrich-farms, don't know if something like this exist at your location - you have to check by yourselfe. At this farm you are able to eat cooked ostrich or get another meal like cooked ostrich eggs. Nearby is a small shop where you are able to buy souvenirs like feathers and eggshells - at this shop my wife bought the ostrich eggshell and the feather. Hope this information may help you. Maybe there is a possibility to buy the eggshells online, just google for it.
comments.author: ThunderChild1

comments.text: Thanks! I've always loved how ostriches look part snake part bird but I don't think we have "ostrich-farms" in Georgia. But like you said there's proabably something online.

We've created a STEM education unit around "Raptor Hacking" - the creation of grabbers from the components of e-NABLE Raptor Reloaded hands. Check out this presentation - http://bit.ly/2lXwY4h - to see how to get students to design, build, and "animalize" Grab-Tors. These files fit a 1 inch PVC pipe but check out the presentation to create any size you want. These files use knuckles scaled to 120% and fingers slightly smaller (117%) to reduce friction. Enjoy!

author: richlehrer

title: Two Jaw Self Centering Parallel Gripper

description.text:
Two Jaw Self Centering Parallel Gripper
Two racks and a pinion open and close the gripper by rotating a handle connected to the pinion. An additional set of guides keep the tooling plates from rotating. 180 degrees of rotation opens the grippers 2.5".

Instructions:

  1. Print out all the parts.
  2. Insert the swivel into the handle and the handle into the gear.
    (add superglue if necessary)
  3. Place the gear assembly and the racks into the gripper base. The racks should be positioned so they are opposite each other and flush with the outside of the base.
  4. Using the dovetail slots slide the guide blocks onto the gripper base until they connect with the detent and lock in plate.
  5. Slide in the two guides into the guide blocks
  6. Mount the tooling plates on the ends of the racks and guide using four M3 x 10mm lg. SHCS's and nuts.
  7. Mount the tooling onto the tooling plates using eight M3 x 6mm lg. SHCS's and nuts.

Required Fasteners:
To mount the tooling plates to the guides.
(4X) M3 x 10mm Lg. Socket Head Cap Screws
(4X)- M3 Hex Nuts

To mount the tooling to the tooling plates. (optional)
(8X) M3 x 6mm Lg. Socket Head Cap Screws
(8X)- M3 Hex Nuts
Note: A set of gripper tooling is provided but additional tooling made for your application can be mounted utilizing the M3 mounting nuts on the tooling plate.

The updated version will operate with a stand hobby servo.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BhH6gq984sc

description.text: questing: This planet looks eerily similar to to earth... but the colours are all OFFFFFFF HELP

The Akaso EK7000 is a great little 4k action camera but the battery cover is a little flimsy and highly likely to break eventually from constantly swapping batteries.
So I designed a printable replacement cover in case mine snaps.
It may well fit other makes of camera, I'd be grateful if you could confirm this in the comments if it fits your camera.
No supports required but print slowly at 0.2mm for best results.
The lens cap in the photos is one of these printed with TPU ...... http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1160621

comments.text:
The 9x19mm round has a case length of 19mm not overall length. The bullet length gets added to this.
Case length 19.15 mm (0.754 in)
Overall length 29.69 mm (1.169 in)

comments.text: Mine was done using the OG slic3r from the website. I've recently switched Prusa's version of Slic3r 1.34.1.24 so the percentages may be different for this version of slic3r. I don't have the file anymore and don't feel like bothering to download it again lol. But size for the gun should be 204mm long according to Glock's website for a 9mm Glock. I don't see why scaling it to the proper size would skew the size for the round, unless the round itself isn't accurate to begin with, or isn't a 9mm round. I didn't quite care for the round since I only needed the frame and the slide so that I could glue them together to make a mold for leather working holsters.
